subtitle: Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is the best kept secret in ufology.
My guest is Jacques Vallee, a ufologist, a
computer scientist, and a venture capitalist.
He is the author of many books including Passport
to Magonia, The Invisible College, Messengers
of Deception, Forbidden Science, which is an
autobiography essentially in four volumes,
Wonders in the Sky, Confrontations, a scientist's
search for alien contact, Dimensions, a casebook
of alien contact, Revelations, Alien Contact
and Human Deception, as well as a novel called
Stratagem and his newest book, co-authored
with Paulo Harris, is Trinity, The Best Kept
Secret.
Jacques is in France today and now I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome, Jacques.
It's a pleasure to be with you.
It's been many years since our previous interview.
It's been a long time since the SRI days
and the parapsychology days and all of that.
It's true, but you've been consistently active amongst all your other interests.
You've maintained your interest in the UFO field.
Your new book, Trinity, written with Paulo
Harris, I guess you'd have to call it something
of a breakthrough.
It really changes our whole understanding of the history of modern ufology.
The field has matured and now the stigma has been removed.
So I'm very happy to have lived long enough to see that.
As you know, many of the people I've worked
with, many of my mentors have not lived long
enough to see that.
I'm happy that I was able to see this and it's a real victory.
Now we can talk more freely about some of the details of the really important cases.
The case at Trinity is remarkable for several reasons.
It's remarkable on its own as an observation
of an object that landed or fell on that land
and the fact that it was observed for 10 days
by the witnesses who were there and that we
have now even more documentation in the new edition of the book.
It's also remarkable because the witnesses never spoke, which is unique in the annals
of the field.
There are good reasons for that that are very
interesting and it's remarkable also because,
as you know, I've worked, as you have, for a
long time with people who had high clearances,
with people who were studying parapsychology
and so on and had access to a lot of the data
and they've never heard of this case.
And again, there are good reasons why that
case was hidden for 70 years until accidentally
it came to light and Paola Harris and a couple
of other people were interested enough to
call the witnesses and reconstruct what happened.
Paola brought me into the case after her own
investigations of three years and I tried
to bring some of the science and the reinvestigation
of the situation in the light of everything
else we know about what the military was doing at that point.
What the military was doing at that point was,
of course, testing, as they say in quotes,
the first atom bomb.
So we are, the location is 20 miles away from
ground zero, you know, in the state of New
Mexico outside the zone where the first atom
bomb was exploded by Enrico Fermi and Oppenheimer
and all these scientists.
So the other characteristic of the case is that it comes at a time in history that is
unique and we have been thinking seriously and, you know, a number of our friends have
been thinking about what that could mean because
the subject arrives out of nowhere, has not
been detected by the radar from the Army.
It's a unique time because there is no Air Force at the time.
So it's not going to be in the Air Force files
when Dr. Hynek, for example, becomes involved.
I never heard Dr. Hynek mention this case, he didn't know about the case.
It went, the case went into the archives of
the Atomic Energy Commission, first of Project
Manhattan and then of the Atomic Secrets.
And the case we know was classified as higher than the atom bomb.
So those are the things that we had to learn
in writing the book, Paola and I, and we're
still discovering new witnesses who are adding
to the understanding of the case and we're
going to continue doing that.
Well, not only did this object appear around
20 miles from ground zero, as I recall it
was also about 20 days after the first atomic explosion.
Yes, and it happened two days after the capitulation of Japan.
And this, you know, I had to relearn history
or learn new history in writing this book.
And this was, the historical part of it was as
emotional for me as it was, you know, meeting
the surviving witness, Mr. Jose Padilla, who
was there as a kid taking care of his family
ranch when the object literally crashed after hitting a communication tower.
So the first witness was actually a bomber pilot who was Mr. Brody, B-R-O-T-H-Y, who
was coming in for a landing at Alamogordo
and was asked by the Alamogordo tower to look
at this communication system that had broken up.
And he saw that the communication tower had been hit by something, it was bent.
And then he saw the object in the brush burning,
actually it wasn't burning, the brush was
burning, but the object was intact.
And then he saw the two kids were there with their horses.
So the initial report to the army places everything
at the site, which is remarkable, as you know,
in the case of Roswell, there was no live witness at the site.
The site was discovered later and they had to reconstruct the story.
Here we have everybody at the site, you know,
at the first instance, at the beginning.
So what I had to relearn was, you know, I'm not much younger than our main witness who
is 85 now.
You know, I was born in 1939 at the beginning of World War II.
My first five years of life were spent in France that was controlled and occupied by
Germany.
And I remember the battles, I remember the bridges being destroyed in our town.
I remember our town was bombed 17 times.
So I remember that part of the war, I did not know much about the war in Japan.
I thought after Hitler died, you know, the war was essentially finished.
And that's not true.
And what I had to relearn about what continued
on the American side with the fight with Japan,
you know, was really overwhelming and the conditions under which Japan capitulated.
There was no Air Force, there was an U.S. Army Air Force.
Of course, there were pilots and there were planes, but they were in Army uniforms.
There were no flying saucers, but the term flying saucer is going to be invented two
years later in 1947 by Kenneth Arnold.
And, you know, of course, there is no organization that keeps track of UFOs.
So term UFO is going to be invented two years later by the U.S. Air Force, okay?
So we are at a time when there is no reference
for the witnesses about something like this
happening on their land.
And they are going to be watching it as a recovery proceeds for the next 10 days.
And in the book, you know, in Trinity, we have reconstructed what happened day after
day after day on that ranch as the Army recovered the craft.
The craft itself, as I recall, you describe it as avocado-shaped.
That's the name, the word they used, of course,
they speak Spanish, you know, most people
in New Mexico spoke English or Spanish indifferently.
They are from Spanish-American families, Spanish-American Indian families.
And there is no flying saucer here, there is no disk.
The pattern that we've studied is a pattern
of this case in parallel with two other cases
that where we know pretty much everything
from the witness point of view and the traces
as we do in the case of Trinity.
The other two cases are Socorro, of course.
And the case of Valençol in France in 1965, 20 years after Trinity.
In all three cases, the object is avocado-shaped or an oval or an egg-shaped.
In all three cases, we have creatures associated with it, forms of life.
They are the size, they are about three feet tall.
They breathe our air, so, you know, you expect,
you know, a euphonaut from a faraway galaxy
to have some sort of breathing equipment and so on.
They don't, they breathe the air, they look human or humanoid.
And in this case, there are three of these
creatures inside the ship, inside the craft.
In the case of Socorro, of course, there are
two creatures on the ground outside the object.
Socorro is not a crash, the object landed in
a place where I've been and I had the pleasure
of taking Dr. Paul Hynick there, the son of Dr. Hynick, we've gone back to that site,
which was so, you know, historic in the study of UFOs.
And then I've also gone to Valençol and interviewed the main witness.
I know a lot about Valençol.
In Valençol, there were, again, two creatures
about three feet tall that not only looked
at the witness, but froze him on the spot, paralyzed him essentially until the object
could take off.
And he had the time to, again, to look at many details.
So in all three cases, some objects have been described or recovered.
And so we are continuing this investigation and we are bringing in several scientists
into the study.
The Socorro, New Mexico case, if I recall correctly, was 1964 or so?
Yes.
Because there are eight miles due north of Trinity.
And the patrolman named Lani Zamora heard a noise, like, thought that something may
have, there may have been an explosion in the desert.
There was a munition shack in that direction,
so he thought that there might have been some
explosion.
And he drove off into the desert, which is not
easy, I mean, I've experimented that myself
with a, you'd better have a four-wheel drive car or a jeep to go there.
And he was confronted with essentially an
oval object on four legs that left deep traces
in the ground.
Now, what's remarkable about Socorro and Valenso,
is that they were not investigated by amateurs,
although amateurs usually do a pretty good job, but they were investigated by official
agencies of, you know, the U.S. government in
Socorro and the French government in Valenso.
In Socorro, the first involved was the police,
but there were three FBI agents who were in
town who joined the investigation to bring
help securing the traces and so on, but they
had no jurisdiction to get into the case.
It was a state inquiry, a state investigation,
but the people from White Sands came into
the investigation because initially they thought
it might have been one of their devices, that
there were a lot of experiments going on at White Sands, although no nuclear experiment
anymore.
All the nuclear stuff had moved to Nevada by then, but they joined to help the local
police during the investigation.
So there were three different agencies, and
of course the Air Force came in and eventually
sent Dr. Hynek there.
I was working closely with Dr. Hynek at the time.
I was just getting my PhD at Northwestern, and
I was working with him on astronomy databases,
and I followed the investigation, and we immediately,
as soon as he came back, took all the data
he was bringing back to help finalize the study of the traces and the case.
So in Valençal, again, five different agencies
of the French government led the study, the
French Air Force, the French intelligence, the Jourdain Marie, and initially the local
police when the men made his first report.
The witness in Valençal is highly regarded
in the area, he's a businessman and a farmer
in the area, well recognized, well respected
as a fighter during the resistance, during
the war.
So he was not someone who was intimidated by
what he saw, he was deeply, deeply affected
by the consequences in his own mind of what he had gone through, and again, as in many
of the cases of close encounters, the human element there is very powerful, very deep,
and has to be analyzed also from the point of view of psychic research in all those
cases.
Well, one of the interesting things to me about
the Socorro case is that it was investigated
by Ray Stanford.
You report on Ray Stanford's involvement, and he's a very interesting figure because
he was also something of a UFO contactee himself
as a teenager, and also developed a career
as a psychic, as a channeler, and a ufologist,
and has recently achieved a lot of publicity
in the field of paleontology.
I regard Ray Stanford as a most interesting figure in the history of all of this.
Well, he was, in that case, he became a research
assistant or a research associate of Dr.
Heinrich, and gathered a number of evidential
data that's very useful that we've picked
up and reproduced with his permission, of course, in our book.
The data is very rich.
It's very interesting to have these two investigators,
Dr. Heinrich and Ray Stanford, jointly but
from different points of view.
One was official, of course, Dr. Heinrich was there on behalf of Project Blue Book,
on behalf of the Air Force, and Ray Stanford
was interviewing people and was running as
a private investigator, so to speak, around
the area, and picked up some very interesting
traces that were, well, let's say confiscated
after a series of lies that were, and promises
that were made to him by some government services,
including people at NASA, but the people at
NASA were not really the guilty ones.
There were other people who came on top of
NASA, confiscated the samples that Ray Stanford
had gathered at the site, and took those samples into classified areas.
So that whole part of the investigation leaves
a strange taste in your mouth when you think
about the way witnesses were treated, in the
way that was ridiculed, and of course now
we are told that all this is now going to be open and the investigation will not be
subject to ridicule in future cases.
We still have, we have yet to see that.
Well, it certainly suggests that at least as far back as 1964 and maybe as far back
as 1945 that some part of the bureaucracy,
whether it's government or corporate or some
combination thereof, has been investigating the UFO phenomena very secretly.
Yes, and in the case of the traces that were picked up, some of it is available.
I mean, I have some of the material that we're going to study.
As you may know, I've been working for the
last few years with Dr. Gary Nolan at Stanford
and other people who have volunteered to help in that study.
I'm not trained in material science, it's a complex area, but I think among our group
we've already made some interesting progress
in that area and we have a number of samples
that we continue to study.
But we know now through various channels where
that particular piece of metal, it's really
an alloy that's very, very high technology, a very interesting alloy that you wouldn't
expect to pick up on the ground outside a little town like Socorro in New Mexico.
We know pretty much where it went, and we also know some of the results.
The truth comes out little by little, but it's clear that there were people who were
definitely investigating UFOs while the message
to the public was, there is nothing to see
here, go away, and this is all dreams and imagination and drunken cowboys.
Well, since you mentioned Dr. Gary Nolan at Stanford University, you're probably aware,
I think, that in the last week or so he's
made a public statement that he expects very
soon there will be major revelations about UFO phenomena, that he's been in touch with
people who have been involved in deeply
embedded secret organizations in the government.
He says they're ready to go public.
In fact, I just heard a couple of days ago of a conference taking place in a few weeks
at Stanford University, and the subject of the conference is alien technology and how
we can integrate it into our corporate structure.
You know, there is a lot of pent-up demand for something to be done.
I cannot speak for Gary.
I think he certainly has made a major impact
on thinking of a number of people in science.
I'm hoping that we're going to see a change.
I wonder, you know, as long as the subject didn't exist, people like me could freely
go around, talk to witnesses, investigate cases, you know, publish whatever we wanted
to publish and so on.
The moment it becomes important, I mean, if you followed the congressional hearings a
few months ago, it has to be considered not
only as an important subject in science, but
potentially as a threat to national security,
which means that it probably has to be classified.
So ironically, the fact that the subject is now admitted to be real, that the witnesses
are not lying, that these things are happening,
that we don't know what they are, may mean
that part of the study, part of the investigation
is going to be more classified than before.
And that's not something that people have really thought about.
You know, people think disclosure, you know,
everything will be, we are going to be told
everything.
Well, the problem is that nobody really has a solution for this.
I mean, you know, it was easy to brush it off
as we don't have enough data, the witnesses
don't remember all the details, we don't
have good photographs, all of which is true.
So we had all these excuses for not most people
going on with their lives, not paying much
attention to this now, you know, it's different.
So the, you know, as you may know, I've been
part of a couple of studies that were classified,
I was called in as a computer scientist to
design an analysis of data databases, actually,
a data warehouse that we built under the Bigelow
Aerospace, space science project, which has
been re renamed ATIP, you know, within the Pentagon nomenclature.
To my knowledge, that that study is still classified and, and properly classified, I
should say, I mean, I'm not, you know, because
so much of our data, which came from all over
the world, you know, 260,000 cases in the same
structure in English, with a fairly sophisticated
structure that was built so that we could build an AI component on top of it.
That's the today it's a high watermark in terms of computer science being applied to
UFO databases.
As you know, I started building files and databases when I was working with Dr. Hynek
at Northwestern, so, you know, back in 1964,
okay, so the problem is that it contains a
lot of personal information about witnesses,
that, you know, it might be okay in a file
of a private file of an amateur group or a civilian group, but, you know, not not in
a file that is part of a federal study.
So there is medical information, there is personal information, all of that will have
to be sanitized before it could be turned over to scientists and I'm hoping of course
that that will happen, there is no reason why it should remain classified as far as
I know, but, you know, I was proud of being
part of that study with a number of research
lectures that were done during that period that still have to see the light of day.
I think those were major contributions, so
I hope they will be public at some point and
can be used in turn within, you know, an academic setting, but we're not there yet.
Well, let's go back to the crash at the Trinity
site before we get too far ahead of ourselves.
I think you indicated that it took the government
about 10 days to actually build a road to
go to the crash site, bring in heavy equipment,
and they took that vehicle or craft out with
them, so it's been in the hands of some
government or quasi-government agency since 1945.
What happened was, and we've reconstructed with
Paola and with Mr. Padilla, we've reconstructed
what happened on each day.
So there is a table in the book that shows the temperature, the rainfall, the weather
in New Mexico at the time, which was well known
because there were a number of, of course,
weather stations, including the ones that the Army was maintaining around the nuclear
site.
So we have all that information and we know what the kids were doing, we know what the
Army was doing, and so on.
The first thing that happens is that the kids
go home after being stunned by what they see
they, they know, you know, this is still in
the atmosphere of war, they are still in the
shops and so on, there are posters that say,
if you see something, you say nothing, okay,
this is ingrained in their mind.
So they are going to report it to Mr. Padilla's
father, who immediately calls the state police.
The state police is going to show up a couple
of days later, and the kids lead the policeman
and the father to the site.
The two adults go inside the object, the small creatures are no longer there.
We speculate with Paola that probably the
Army had sent a patrol right there immediately
to make, to see what had fallen there and to clean up the site.
So when the kids go back there, one day has passed when there was nobody on the site,
and now they see that the site has been altered,
somebody has been there, probably the Army,
and they've done some cleanup, and the object
is there, one panel is missing from the hit
against the communication tower, and they can see inside, the two adults go inside.
When they come out, they have a change of attitude, as the kids describe it.
They tell the kids, look, nobody talks about that ever.
This is not for our family, this is not for us.
You don't talk in school to other kids, let the Army handle it.
This is way beyond what we should do.
And the next day, of course, the kids are going
to be there, they are watching the cattle.
Those two kids are very bright.
I mean, the kids were growing up quickly during
the war, they were in an environment, there
was no, there was very little playing, I mean,
the things were serious, many of the adults
were at either in Germany or in the Pacific on ships and so on, there had been deaths
all around.
So this is very serious to them, and that's why they will not, at the time of Roswell,
they are not going to come up and talk to the press or reveal what they've seen, it's
going to remain a family secret for a long time.
The sergeant arrives, of course, there is a fence around the ranch.
An officer arrives at the home of Mr. Padilla,
the father, Faustino Padilla, and says, Senor,
tenemos que ir a su rancho, we have to go
to your land, to your ranch, because we have
lost one of our weather balloons.
Of course, the officer spoke Spanish, and that's one thing that I've read a number
of books, you know, I mean, you study physics,
I mean, there is no way to avoid studying
Trinity and, you know, the atom bomb and that
whole story and the careers of people like
Oppenheimer and, you know, and the other luminaries
of science who were there at the Trinity site.
So all of them spoke English, and then after
the war, they went back to Princeton or Chicago
and so on to teach physics.
The population there spoke mostly Spanish.
So the officers, the army officers were Mexican-American,
they spoke Spanish, and so he's asking permission
to cut the fence.
Mr. Padilla says, why do you need to cut my fence?
I mean, there is a perfectly good gate there
for the cattle, you know, for the truck carrying
the cattle to go in and out.
And the officer says, no, senor, we need a real
large truck to pick up our weather balloon.
So we're going to build a big gate, and we're
going to build a road on your property to
go get the weather balloon, our experimental weather balloon.
The father says, you know, weather balloons,
you launch weather balloons all the time from
White Sands, and a lot of them land on my
ranch and I pick them up for you, so I'm going
to go get them.
So he goes into the back room, he comes back
with an armful of weather balloons that he
has carefully folded to return them to the army.
I mean, everybody knew you had to help the army as much as you could.
And the officer says, no, it's a different kind of weather balloon.
So they cut the gate, they put in, you
know, a new gate, and they bring in a truck.
And here, you know, there was a funny episode
because I almost had a fight with Paola, you
know, Paola Harris said, why do you want to
go back and ask Mr. Padilla about the truck?
I mean, you know, it's an army truck.
I said, yes, but the number of wheels on that
truck is going to tell me the weight of the
avocado, you know, and we're going to find out if it's a weather balloon.
And they brought in one of the big army trucks that could carry two tanks.
You know, this was a truck with a big tractor,
and behind the tractor was what they called
a low boy that could be lower close to the ground to load tanks.
So this gives us an estimate of the weight of
the, and there are other factors, the weight
of the object.
The object was the size of two trucks.
It was about 15 feet high and, you know, very,
very large, egg shaped or avocado shaped.
And it must have weighed between two and four tons.
If you remember the estimate of the object at Socorro by several people, including the
army was five tons from the traces it left,
it left deep traces in the ground at Socorro.
So again, that eliminates the idea that this
was a hoax, that somebody was playing a joke
on Project Manhattan.
Well, you know, you wouldn't want to play a joke on the group of people who had just
exploded the first atomic bomb, you know, two days after the capitulation of Japan.
So and again, the coincidence or the comparison
with these three cases, and again, here I'm
thinking as an information scientist, isn't
going to think in terms of one case at a time.
You're going to think in terms of patterns.
And here the pattern is at least three cases
where we have the same type of craft, the
same type of occupant, the same type of materials
that were being recovered, you know, and,
and those are among the best studied cases,
the most intensely stated cases by government
agencies, you know, in the whole history of the phenomenon.
So I think that's what the book is all about.
You mentioned in the book that the children
described the short humanoid-like creatures.
I think the Spanish word was something like machacampa, meaning praying mantis.
They compare them and, you know, I had the
privilege of being able to work from the first
recordings that Paola Harris did with both of the witnesses.
By the time I got involved, Remi Baca had
died, but Remi Baca was alive when, when Paola
first became involved.
So we have separate recordings, long recordings of both of them separately.
And both of them, when they talk about, and
I've had some experience analyzing transcripts
of, you know, when I was working on the early
internet, you know, as you remember, we did
some experiments together in parapsychology
using the networks and so on, they analyzing
the transcripts from those conversations.
And it's very interesting because both of them speak in the past, you know, we went
there, we saw this, it was like this, always in the past, you know, in the tense.
But then when they are close to it, they jump
to the present all of a sudden, it's as if
all of a sudden they are there and they say,
they do this, they walk, they change, you
know, and they look, the little men, you know, seem to be in distress and so on.
And then they say the creatures, and I tried
to pin down Mr. Padilla about this, I said,
sometimes you talk to them as if they were
little men, they were about your size, I mean,
you know, a nine-year-old kid, they were a little over three feet tall, so as we can
tell, and they look human, I mean, they had two eyes and a small nose, a small mouth,
they breathed our air, but then you talk to them
as if they were insects, you know, comprimacha,
and they use all these terms to describe insects in Spanish.
Well, he told me, well, you know, there were
some aspects of them that were not completely
human and we were afraid and we wanted to help them because we knew when you are in
front of an accident in an isolated area,
remember, they are 10 miles from the nearest
place where they could even call a doctor, okay, so they know that they are the first
responders, they have to be there and bring assistance.
And Mr. Padilla, the nine-year-old Jose wanted
to go in and help the occupants, the creatures,
and Remy Baca was seven years old, you know,
two years younger, was in distress, he was
crying, he said, well, you know, you go there
if you want to, there's no way I'm going
to go there, and finally they just stayed
frozen at the place, you know, watching those
creatures go back and forth inside the object,
they never stepped outside, and being fascinated
with what they saw and really unable to do anything.
So there were those two aspects, yes, they
were little men, they related to them as little
men, but there were some aspects of them that
scared them and they told them this is not
normal at all.
And they watched while the army loaded that vehicle onto the truck, and I gather they
also picked up a few souvenirs themselves.
The word souvenir here is very interesting, I asked Mr. Padilla, why did you want to go
inside that object, and he said, I wanted to
go in and pick up a souvenir, and you know,
so far the witnesses have spoken English or Spanish, I know a little Spanish so I can
follow, you know, most of that, but souvenir
is a French word, what is it doing in the
middle of New Mexico, you know, when we're
talking about a crashed UFO essentially, and
he said, well, souvenir, you know, there were
many people in our families who were not coming
back from the front, they were not coming
back from the Pacific, or they were not coming
back from Germany, and we had to have something
to remember them by, and it could be an object
a piece of clothing, it could be a pipe, it could be a pair of glasses, that's what we
called a souvenir.
And you know, in doing this, at impressing yourself in the time, you would hit those
moments that were so precious, but to me were
so were also, you know, emotional, because
you know, this was serious, I mean, this was,
this touched their lives, you know, and in
the last witness that we found that, you know,
is now in the book, the first thing you need
to talk about was the deaths in his family,
the children who died of radiation, you know,
and you know, before we could talk about what
he had seen at the site and so on, he brought
up the pictures of the young kids who died
because of the radiation left by the explosion
of the bomb.
The history books and the physics books that
I read and studied say that there was a test
at Trinity, Trinity was a test of the first atom bomb.
Well, when you do a test in physics, you know,
you take a glass and there's some liquid and
you put some chemical in it and you observe some reaction.
And if it works, you get a patent or you, you know, you built a larger experiment.
You cannot do that with an atom bomb, you know, either it works or it doesn't.
Many physicists thought the bomb would never work.
You know, it was the genius of and we call
fairly Oppenheimer and their team that designed,
you know, the explosion principle actually
two bombs, you know, one was an uranium bomb
and the other one was a plutonium bomb.
The plutonium bomb was the one that was called
tested, but it had, when you look at the power,
it had the same power as the bomb that was launched on Nagasaki, you know, an estimate
of 19 kilotons that destroyed the town of Nagasaki.
You couldn't make a small atom bomb.
So it had the same power as the bomb.
And one thing that I found, we went to the, to the, to the test site itself when it was
open and we got some brochures from the army
that are not in most libraries and so on.
In the, in the army brochure, which is only
about 10 pages describing the, you know, the
building of a bomb for Project Manhattan,
they say that following the test at Trinity,
they changed the altitude where the bomb would
blow up because they realized that there was
too much radioactivity left at the site.
The radioactivity is not why you build the bomb.
You know, you build the bomb, the destructive
power of the bomb is in the power of the explosion
and the wind that will destroy any structures
within, you know, fairly wide radius.
Of course we have much bigger bombs now, but they
didn't think of the impact of the radioactivity
at the site.
So the two bombs that were dropped on Japan were recalibrated to blow up at 2000 feet
up in the air and not at ground zero.
And I had never, I don't think people know that.
I don't think physicists know that.
I don't think it's in the history books.
You know, it's in the army brochures and you
know, it's to the, to the credit of the army
that they realized that they should try to
minimize as much as possible the radioactive
impact that devastated that part of New Mexico.
And it confirmed me at the time of the explosion,
watching the explosion computed the power
and found it was four times more powerful than what the calculations indicated.
You indicated in your book that not all of the plutonium that went into that bomb that
was exploded at Trinity was actually ignited in the nuclear reaction.
A good deal of it was scattered throughout the country.
I think you indicated maybe over a range of a hundred miles or so.
A lot of the unspent plutonium was showered over a wide area of New Mexico where there
were people living.
And the wind, again, we reconstructed the
trajectory of the wind after the Trinity explosion.
The wind would have taken the cloud, the radioactive
cloud, north, initially north, northeast,
and then turned to the west and went over the area where those kids were living.
So no wonder, you know, there was such an impact.
Mr. Parilla heard the explosion and had bleeding
in his ear and was after that, you know, his
was, had a punctured ear for the rest of his life.
His mother went blind in one eye when she saw the explosion.
And so the devastation was profound.
And you can, you know, you can excuse the
initial secret because for a number of strategic
reasons, it had to be secret until they knew
that they had a weapon that could terminate
the war.
But after that, you know, as many people say now, you know, why didn't they tell us?
Why didn't they tell us not to drink the water, you know, on the reservoirs?
Why didn't they tell us to slaughter the
cattle, not take it to the market, you know?
And all those things people are still talking about now.
And Parilla and I have been fairly powerfully
affected by what we heard in those conversations.
We decided to give a percentage of the proceeds
of the book to an organization that is coming
to the help of survivors of the atom bomb and all the sequelae, which continue in New
Mexico in that area.
There were 60,000 people, you know, within the
wide area that were exposed to the explosion
and to the sequelae of the explosion.
Well, you raise a very interesting parallel in your book.
You ask, as many people probably did, how
could it be that some civilization from some
distant location is so advanced that they can
build a craft that would come to our planet
and then crash?
It seemed as if that was ironic, but you compare
that to the way we treated our own people
at the time of the Trinity explosion.
Maybe it wasn't the crash.
Maybe it was designed to do a hard landing and maybe it was some sort of a gift in the
shape of a warning also, and, you know, I'm not enough of a historian of that period to
know what the impact would have been in different countries and so on.
The army, contrary to what people think, many
people in the army, including General Eisenhower
and General Sherman and other generals, did not want to use the atom bomb.
They wanted to finish the war with a conventional battle.
The Pentagon had ordered 500,000 purple hearts
in anticipation of the final battle in Japan.
Japan had built fortifications in the north of Japan.
They expected the Russians to invade Japan from the north, re-armed by us, re-armed by
the United States, and Stalin had, of course,
you know, Berlin and Germany was finished.
The Red Army was sweeping through Manchuria and China, ready to attack Japan from the
north, the American fleet of the Pacific,
which at the time had 100 aircraft carriers,
100 aircraft carriers.
Some of them were just old ships that had been with a flat bed on top, you know, to
have a maximum number of planes available,
but, you know, those are in the records that
we have studied.
And so the fleet was going to help in the invasion of Japan from the north.
The Japanese were not, the army in Japan was not ready to surrender.
It was, you know, the emperor who decided by
himself that he would not submit his people
to that final battle, which would have been,
you know, the largest battle equivalent to
the Normandy invasion, you know, would happen again in the north of Japan.
And in studying the books, the history books
that have been published in the last five
years, you know, about all that, now that
all the archives are open and can be studied
by, you know, academics, you realize what
the impact would have been and why President
Truman made the decision to use a vote against
the advice of some of his greatest generals.
And we haven't used the atom bomb since then.
You know, Russia was known to be working on the bomb.
It was clear that eventually other countries
would have it, you know, the UK, France, Israel,
and eventually China would have the bomb.
And that is, that was the reason, you know, when John Eisenhower went to see Mr. Truman
said, we're going to change the nature of war,
it's going to be completely out of control.
And we will not be able to have a, you know,
conventional solution, armed solution to conflicts.
You know, history is going to be in a different regime.
Well, why is it?
It must have been very tempting to use a war,
to use the bomb during the wars in the last
50 years.
And it wasn't.
Could Trinity have played a role?
Could that have been taken as a warning?
We know that there have been conversations,
classified conversations at the highest levels
within, you know, between the different countries
about the UFOs and about, of course, nuclear
weapons.
Those conversations go on all the time at the top level.
Could that have been a factor?
You know, I don't know.
We have to leave that to historians and to, you
know, people in those levels of the government.
Back to the Trinity crash itself and the idea
of souvenirs, I also want to introduce at
this point the book by Philip Corso, The Day
After Roswell, in which he intimated that his
role at the time, being part of military intelligence,
was to collect some of the artifacts from
UFO crashes and see if they could be
analyzed and maybe even used by corporations.
You report extensively that after this crash at
Trinity, the children on the ground, including
their father, found large amounts of what might
appear to be fiberglass or fiber optic-like
cables that they used for Christmas tree decorations.
Yes.
Well, you know, that's what you do with extraterrestrial material.
You put it on the Christmas tree, right?
I mean, everybody knows that.
Well, the kids, at the time of the impact of the object on the tower, one panel was
broken up and as a result of it breaking up,
the ground was covered with these fibers.
The kids were very intrigued with it because
the fibers, when you took them to a dark place,
the fibers glowed with different colors.
Now, I've met with Colonel Corso.
As you know, Paul Harris has published a book
of conversations with Colonel Corso when he
was in Italy and he could speak freely.
His English book, you know, was sanitized by different people who didn't want certain
things to be published.
And he was, in fact, very, very angry at his publisher for sanitizing his report.
But in his Italian book and his books outside
the U.S., he was free to go into more details.
Well, he mentions that he had the job after the war of gathering those materials and
turning them over to different laboratories that were under classified contracts with
the Army to study the materials and see if they could be applied in some way and could
be useful either in commerce or could be useful to the military.
So I spent a couple of days when under the
project of Mr. Bigelow in Las Vegas, we invited
Colonel Corso to speak to us and we had a chance to interview him at Planck also.
I met him on two different occasions, but
there in Las Vegas, we had two days with him
and I had a chance to have a private conversation with him.
And I, you know, I raised the question of
those fibers because I told him, look, Colonel,
you describe this as fiber optics, but fiber
optics doesn't glow, you have different colors
on the length of the fiber.
I mean, you put a particular sine wave or a particular signal at one end, it comes out
at the other, carried by the light through the
glass, but it doesn't glow along the length
of the fiber.
And so what you picked up at Trinity and other places was something different.
And he agreed with me that you cannot call it really fiber optic.
It was an optical effect.
The kids were fascinated with it because it glowed in all these different colors.
As we know, Paola found a later witness, Sabrina
Padilla, who grew up on the ranch a few years
after the crash.
And she remembers her grandfather studying
pieces of material that he had picked up after
the army was gone, after the object was taken away.
There was still a lot of stuff in the bushes.
And some of that stuff actually was the fiber
you indicate, the type of fiber that glowed.
And she described it and she also said, you shouldn't really play with that very much
because it hurts your fingers, it hurts your hands.
So we've been studying those records with a number of scientists on our team and trying
to make sense of all the materials that were
found in connection with the crash at Trinity.
And as I recall, she indicated that her grandfather,
which would be Jose Padilla's father, had
collected a whole gunny sack full of this fiber.
And the two kids gave it to people in the neighborhood to put on the Christmas trees.
And in those days, there wasn't all the Christmas
ornaments that we have now by the thousands
and so on, glowing things.
And in many of those houses, the electrical system was somewhat primitive.
At the Padilla household, the bedrooms didn't have electricity.
So it was fascinating for the kids to have these fibers that glowed by themselves in
different colors.
So if I recall correctly, one of the children,
I forget which, Remy or Jose, went into the
craft and pulled out a piece of metal that
had been there and kept it as, I think, what
they called a treasure.
They called it a souvenir and they called
it the tesoro, the treasure, because to them
it was just such an incredible thing.
It is, and Mr. Padilla donated it to me to take it to different labs and I have done
that and it's still under study.
So far, and also other people had done, had already done studies, Remy Baca had taken
it to Los Alamos, where friends of his had done an analysis.
As far as we can tell, it's a human object.
It's a bracket, the kind of bracket you would
find in a, maybe not in a windmill, but maybe
in a watermill or in a farm device where you
need to transmit rotating motion into different
other kinds of motion.
For example, opening veins or triggering other action within the machine.
So there are many, many forms of that kind of device.
I think, and other people disagree with me,
and that's fair, but I think the Army brought
it there and put it on the wall, probably to wrap up a cable, an electrical cable.
It may have served for other things as well,
maybe to generate, to help generate power,
but it's a kind of improvised piece of equipment
that the Army is very good at, you know, when
they are in the middle of nowhere.
Now, they would have had power at the site, because I used to drive a Jeep years ago,
and I know a Jeep can generate power.
If you're in an isolated area and you need a light or you need a motor, you can hook
it up to the Jeep and you'll have electrical power.
And so it's a reliable source of power, and
they may have needed to work there at night,
and they may have needed to have a light inside the object.
Anyway, José Padilla, Mr. Padilla, who is, you know, our live witness today, recalls
crawling into the craft on the last day.
The craft was on its side on the low buoy on the truck.
The reason it was on its side is that otherwise
it couldn't go under the overpass, you know,
of the, you know, the American Highway that's just a few miles away.
And so it would have hurt the bridge of the overpass.
So it's on the side and, you know, a nine-year-old
kid is going to crawl in to see what's inside.
All the soldiers have gone nearby to have a bite to eat before they drive at night.
They are going to drive the truck covered with a tarp, but the tarp is open and the
kid goes in and he pops out, he has a wrench,
you know, that he uses to pop out that bracket.
And that bracket they kept as a treasure.
They were able to hide it from everybody for many years.
They actually didn't quite remember where it was for a while.
And they found it again because Mr. Baca, Rémi Baca, borrowed it from José Padilla
to have it tested at Los Alamos.
So we have the results of a series of tests and then we've done our own tests of it.
There is no question it's human.
It's an alloy of aluminum called silumin, which is stronger than aluminum that was in
fact used in the 40s in a number of applications.
So it was fairly easy to manufacture an object out of it.
It's not high-tech.
You know, the lab at college or high school would have had the necessary equipment to
make a mold and make that aluminum object.
Well, just when you think you have a neat, pat answer that this is a human-made object
that the Army put into the UFO, there's this
other story about the, if I recall correctly,
a shepherd who had been sleeping in a shack
or a barn or something where they had hidden
this object who was disturbed at night by small creatures who apparently had come to
find it.
Again, he was an itinerant worker who took care of the sheep.
He was a sheep herder and that the farm or ranch would go at the time when the sheep
are going to be taken to be slaughtered.
And he's sleeping in this little shack, has heard nothing about the story.
The children have not, of course, not spoken to him about what they saw.
In the middle of the night, he's awakened by
small diminutive men who are in that little
shack with him, and they apparently point
to an area where the object has been buried.
The men doesn't know that the kids have buried
it there to hide it, to make sure that nobody
knows where it is, neither the military nor the family, because they want to keep it as
their secret.
It's their link to the reality of what they've seen.
And he's frightened, of course, by these creatures, has no idea why they are there.
There is a big light outside from an object that's somewhere in the brush.
Of course, he picks up his gun and the creatures disappear and go away.
That's again the kind of thing that
illustrates the complexity of a case like that.
There are stories like that in Valensoll that
I know about, but they have not been reported
officially at any time, because the people there wanted to keep the secret.
And you know, we have the illusion, and many
scientists have this delusion that if something
happens they can go there and interview the witnesses and gather the report.
Well, up to a point that's true, but it's very clear that in many cases the witnesses
are going to only give you part of the story unless you can gain their confidence.
And in the case of Trinity, Paola and I were
proud to have been able to gain the confidence
of the witnesses, because they know that we're
serious about this and we've invested a big
part of our lives studying this and trying to understand the mystery, and that creates
a bond with the witnesses.
That's not going to be the case if you just
come from Stanford or you come from Princeton
and you know, with a questionnaire and you ask somebody to fill out, you know, answer
questions A, B and C and D, you know, that's
not the way you're going to learn what really
happened.
As I recall from your book, The Sheepherder came to, I think it was Mr. Padilla, Jose
Padilla's father, and said, I'm never going to go back to that shack again because of
what happened.
Again, they speak Spanish and he says, you know, I cannot work for you again because
there are too many strange things around here.
So he and the father doesn't know about the
little creatures and The Sheepherder, again,
at that point, there is also a religious connotation.
You know, when Dr. Hynek interviewed Officer
Zamora, bloody Zamora did not want to speak
to Dr. Hynek until he had gone to church to confession and spoken to the priest about
what he had seen because he was troubled.
Remember, he hadn't slept that night.
He was deeply troubled by the two creatures
that he had seen because he knew this wasn't
quite human.
They looked kind of human, there had been an
exchange visually with them, they had looked
directly at him and then they went into the craft and the thing took off and he wanted
to speak to the priest before he would speak to Dr. Hynek.
Now, this is not superficial.
This isn't just, you know, like an ordinary car accident or something like that.
It's something that had a deep impact on the witnesses.
And you throughout your career, I remember
first hearing you speak about this, Jacques,
I think in 1972, you've always emphasized the spiritual and paranormal aspects of the
phenomenon, that there's a part of what's going
on that really defies all of our conventional
ways of interpreting what's happening.
That cannot be ignored.
And it comes out whether, you know, whether you like it or not.
It comes out in the testimony.
For example, in Valençal, the witness for a
while couldn't sleep and then he would sleep
during the day.
He would sleep, you know, 20 hours out of the day and he couldn't.
And again, the impact on the consciousness
of people is part of the story and it cannot
be ignored.
Both Mr. Padilla and Mr. Baca had horrible dreams, recurring dreams for several years
where they saw people falling out of the clouds,
people falling out of tall buildings and that
would wake them up suddenly in the middle of the night.
And those dreams would happen again and again and again.
They happened for several years as they grew up.
So the psychic impact is part of it and it has to be...
The problem is that most of the investigators,
you know, are trained in science and they
want hard facts, they want measurements, they want all of that and they don't...
In many cases, they don't appreciate the witness
as a human instrument that has recorded much
more than just the physical data, you know, at the time.
In France, France is an exception to that.
There is a UFO government research project
in France that has gone on for about 40 years
under different forms and different names,
but continually accepting testimony from the
French public.
It's not the military, it's the French Space
Agency, which is a civilian scientific agency.
So the files are open except for the privacy
of the witnesses, but essentially the databases
are open.
And the reason I'm in France now, I'm in Paris,
as you can see from my surroundings, but I'm
here to prepare for an international meeting
of the French Space Agency four weeks from
now, where the six countries are going to be represented, including a representative
of NASA who is going to speak officially on the
new openness within NASA towards the subject.
And the other countries are, you know, the UK, Sweden, Holland, Spain, and Italy and
Germany, and of course, France, comparing, it's a closed meeting.
It's a meeting of scientists who have submitted,
you know, testimony and submitted research.
And it will be two very full days of analysis.
But in the US, I've never heard anybody talking
about what's going on in other countries.
It's all about the limits, you know, and the limits, of course, is very interesting.
But everything that was presented to Congress
were military cases or formally classified
cases that came from the government itself.
90% of the databases we have, and I speak
with knowledge of the databases, is civilian.
It's not covered by secrets.
It comes from, it's certainly covered by privacy
and so on of the witnesses, but it consists
of observations by civilians away from military facilities.
And as good as the military observations are,
because of the instruments that they have
access to, you know, you have radar, you have
infrared cameras, you have all of that, but
those are limited to certain areas and certain situations.
What about the other 30% of the data?
I mean, when are we going to look at?
When are we going to look at the data around the world?
You know, the US, the land occupied by the American public is 1.7% of the surface of
the earth.
Okay.
Well, what about the rest of it?
You know, and can we study a problem, which is a scientific problem, by limiting it to
formally classified military cases of the last five years in one small country?
Yes, as I recall, you just said there are over
200,000 cases that you have in a database.
But that's only the beginning.
If people were allowed to come out and describe
what they've seen, you'd have much more.
Now there is, of course, a phase of the analysis
of these databases where you need to purge
all the cases that can be explained, and a
majority of the reports can, in fact, be explained.
So the scientists and the skeptics have a point there, you know, that those reports
cannot be taken as they come.
They have to be, somebody has to do an analysis
that can be done, by the way, with AI, I've
designed AI programs that can help you sift through the report from the witnesses and
guide you.
The AI isn't going to give you the answer, but
the AI can tell you among 50 or 60 different
possible natural explanations.
Have you thought of this?
Have you thought of asking this?
Have you tested such and such a thing?
And it can guide you towards a natural explanation in the majority of the cases.
So when we say 260,000 cases, it doesn't mean
260,000 cases that you would send to the Academy
of Sciences for them to review.
Out of that, there may be 20,000 cases that
we could send to the Academy of Sciences for
them to review.
Now, the last time the Academy looked at a
report, it was a condon report, and they said
there's nothing to it, you know, the subject doesn't exist.
So I'm again, I'm happy to have lived long
enough to see the Academy reverse its decision
on the phenomenon.
I'm happy to be alive now.
Well even the condon report itself, as I recall,
gosh, it goes back to the late 1960s, I think.
But even though the summary statement said
there's nothing here, if you read the report
in detail, it certainly seemed as if there were quite a few valid cases.
Well, they had selected cases, and in their
analysis, over 20% were certainly not explained
by them.
And a case like Socorro, I mean, why didn't they look at Socorro?
Socorro, you know, the witnesses were still alive.
Dr. Hynick and I were the first two scientists
who testified before the Condon Committee
at the University of Colorado.
We could have given them all the files about
Socorro, but Socorro, of course, has remained
unidentified, and the Condon Committee never looked at it.
And they were, you know, they were close by.
Now, if I remember correctly, Condon himself,
it is now known, had written a memo before
he ever began the study saying that his intention
was to basically make sure that it got dismissed.
He thought that he would… it was obviously,
you know, not a scientific subject, and that
he was doing a favor.
He was helping science by getting rid of the
subject once and for all with his report.
I think he really believed that.
I had a couple of occasions of private conversations
with him when I was in Boulder, and he really
thought that, well, somebody had to dismiss
all this because it really wasn't very serious.
It reminds me very much of the AIR report about remote viewing.
Again, it seemed to be a deliberate effort to dismiss a very valid subject area.
You know, the two subjects are very similar.
It would be a dream for a sociologist to study
the public reaction and the scientific reaction.
To anomalies that, you know, in both cases…
I believe, as somebody says in our book, that there are no anomalies in nature.
You know, how could there be anomalies?
I mean, nature is one thing, right?
I mean, things happen, and then either you understand them or you don't.
And those we don't understand, we say they are anomalies.
So it's a pejorative word that we use.
But you know, if you brought somebody from the days of Archimedes and you showed him
the device we're using now to communicate,
you know, across many miles, across an ocean
and so on, he would say this is magic, this is anomalies, this is a miracle, you know,
it's going to go away and never happen again.
And you and I know very well how this thing works, right?
Very interesting.
Well, before we close our conversation, I would like to point out another aspect of
your book that you went into largely in footnotes
actually about a report made by the physicist
Eric Davis, who had a lengthy communication with, I believe it was Admiral Ray Wilson,
Thomas Ray Wilson if I recall correctly, who
had been in charge of military intelligence
and began looking into the UFO phenomenon, wanted to know what the military knew about
it.
He was a high-ranking figure in military intelligence
and apparently, although I guess he is subsequently
denied it, he told Eric Davis that this was
classified well above top secret, well above
anything having to do with nuclear energy,
but that the government has secretly empowered
corporations with large budgets employing
hundreds of people to try and reverse engineer
these recovered craft and other technology associated with them.
As you know, I'm a close colleague of Dr. Eric
Davis, I have very high admiration and
respect for his work in physics and for the work that we did together, first as part of
NEDS in Nevada and then on the classified project of BASS and ECIP.
It's difficult for me as it is for him to talk very much about that.
I can tell you that I trust Eric has an amazing
memory, an amazing ability to describe situations
from the past in very great detail and I trust him.
On the other hand, as you know, as you mentioned,
the Admiral has denied that the thing happened
in that particular way, so I'm really not at
liberty based on the fact that the project
is still classified.
I don't think I should comment on my own opinion about the situation.
My hope, the hope of many of us is that in
the development of the congressional election
that there will be permission given to more
people to come up and testify about what they
know about what happened and so on.
The public must realize that there are good men
and women who have been in highly responsible
positions involving this phenomenon for a very long time and that they have suffered
the consequences in their careers.
Again, I'm delighted to see that the stigma
is being removed and I'm grateful to Congress
for doing this.
Well, I think it would be fair to say, Jacques,
given that NASA is currently involved in launching
a new moon rocket, which I understand is 15%
more powerful than the last rockets that went
to the moon nearly half a century ago, that
the effort to reverse engineer alien technology
has at least not progressed so far that NASA is utilizing it.
Again, the question is going to be, and that
was reflected, if my memory serves, in the
earlier hearings we saw, there was an argument
that this really should not be shared with
foreign countries because of the potential that
this could lead to breakthroughs in physics
and of course, breakthroughs in technology for the United States.
Now, that's an argument that I'm sure Congress is going to consider seriously.
I also know of cases that should be brought to the attention of American science that
come from other countries that are willing to share them but are still afraid of the
ridicule, again, on the stigma that has resulted
from the US keeping the subject at a level
of ridicule, of public ridicule, and nobody, no
astronomer, no physicist in France or Germany
or the UK or Holland wants to come out with a story that is going to be laughed at by
the American media, it's going to be laughed
at on CNN, on ABC, and on other American media.
So those fires should be studied, they should
be pursued, they give us, just like the case
of Valenso, throws an extraordinary light on
what happened at Socorro and what happened
at Trinity.
I happen to have investigated all three of those cases, you know, I know the witnesses
in all three of those cases.
Now if we limit the data, and there are valid
arguments why some data may have to remain
classified, if only because the object was detected with a classified sensor.
You know, think of the limits, we only know half of what happened with the limits, the
other half is still classified, probably because
of the sensors, or advanced technology that
has not been declassified.
So those are, again, there are proper arguments
for keeping certain things classified, and
other countries, you bet, other countries are going to do the same thing.
But what about the civilian cases, can't we,
or the cases that do not involve national
security today, can't we share that, you know?
And I think that's a problem that Congress
is going to have to face, again, I heard two
different arguments in the Congressional hearings that we saw very recently.
One argument was we need to keep all that classified.
One argument was we need to share this and open the doors and the windows.
I know that in one of the promotional pieces for
this upcoming conference at Stanford University
on alien technology, the pitch for selling tickets to the conference was that whoever
can master this technology, whether it's a government or a corporation, will in effect
be able to rule the world.
You know, there are lots of very bright people
in Silicon Valley and other places, and they
certainly could be inspired by some of the things that witnesses are describing.
But we're only at the very beginning of that,
and I'm a little bit, you know, leery of jumping
to conclusions as we just begin the study.
And very, very little of what I've seen so far involves the history of cases that goes
back not only 70 years, but much further back.
And you know, people will have to take the time to study that.
The problem is that as we go on, more and more
of those witnesses are no longer available.
We're very fortunate to have, you know,
Mr. Padilla alive with an excellent memory of
his, you know, at age 86 or 87.
But many of the other witnesses we'd like to interview from the days of Trinity have
passed away.
You also report in your book that it seems
as if there was some sort of a covert effort
to interfere with your investigation.
I think in one case, for example, one of the
witnesses whom you interviewed received a
mysterious phone call saying you wouldn't be coming.
A few years ago, I would have been scared of that.
But understanding, and this was not done by a
joker, I mean, this is, this had to be somebody
who had access to four minds, and, you know,
in his work, or her work, his work, because
was a man's voice, but, you know, there are people who do that.
And so I'm not, you know, the investigation we've done is pretty open.
So we were not, after the initial surprise, we were, we got used to that.
That happened twice.
You know, somebody called the witness on our
behalf and said we wouldn't come or we would
be or something else was going to happen and so on.
So it's interference and that reinforces, you know, our impression that somebody has
been watching all along and, you know, and we can only hope they are on our side.
You also point out that at one time you went
to visit the actual crash site of the Trinity
crash and discovered that since the children
had been there and how they remembered it,
there was poisonous plants that had apparently
been planted just over that spot, were not
really found elsewhere in the adjacent parts of the ranch.
Yes, and we know from the testimony of Sabrina
Padilla, again, who was growing there as a
little girl in the years after the sighting,
that there was the large area where this took
place was burnt as if to destroy any trace
that might have remained of the crash itself.
So yes, there was interference and people in New Mexico who have investigated other
sites will tell you that those sites have been peppered with metal objects, you know,
beer cans and different mechanical devices and so on.
And I've actually been with Dr. Nolan on the
ranch that was absolutely peppered with metal,
rusty metal parts of mechanical engines that
were all over the place rusting away so that
if you came there with a metal detector, you
couldn't find the things that may have been
buried under the ground.
Yes, so, you know, it's a silly game, but when we have the witness, you know, we can
go beyond that.
It's only an indication that something important
happened there, important enough that somebody
wanted to hide it forever.
I suppose it means that somebody is studying
whatever artifacts were retrieved and wanted
to make sure that nobody else had the opportunity to study them as well.
You know, that's fine, and again, that's understandable
that you want to have first crack at the secrets.
On the other hand, over time, you know, some
of those things in scientific circles, people
will talk after a while or will seek advice, confidentially or openly.
There is one, I've had several occasions where
that happened to me, and I can now talk about
it because the man who told me the story has
been dead for over 20 years, but he was a
very distinguished leading engineer at a three-letter,
not a three-letter agency, but a three-letter
company that is known all over the world for
those three letters, and that now is the choice
for you.
But he was a man who invented the magnetic coating of memory devices, thereby earning
literally billions and billions of dollars
for the company who held the patents and still
does.
He was picked by a project that must have been very close to what Cardinal Corso was
doing, and he was, remember the way those projects work is that they will parcel out
different pieces of what they have, and they
will tell a scientist who is the world expert
in that particular field.
This was again the inventor of magnetic memory
for computers, that says a lot, and we had
occasion to work on a particular project together,
so he trusted me and told me that story, that
he was given a piece of something that I would
not describe, that he could not analyze, that
he did not have the devices that would
permit him to understand what that thing did.
Now he could analyze something about the structure.
The structure was very sophisticated, and it
was obviously built for a purpose by somebody,
but he could not find a use for it in industry,
in American industry, and he returned it to
the people who had given it to him, and with his report of his analysis.
Now there are a number of these people who
would be, they were approached not necessarily
through their companies, they probably would
have been approached as individual leading
experts in a particular area, to tell us what you think about this.
What could it be used for?
Now he was smart enough to know that it came
from a UFO site, that it would not have come
from a Russian lab, or an Israeli lab, or a French lab, so he could see through that.
But again, those things were kept secret, I
think that it's time to let American science
and eventually world science opine on what those things could do.
Remember the object, we know quite a bit about
the object at Trinity, at least three humans
went inside, plus the military of course worked inside.
We know the characteristics of the dimensions
inside, we know that the floor is flat, we
know that the kids inspected the bottom when
it was on the side, on the trailer, ready
to be taken away.
There was the only space where there could be a propulsion system, was about the size
of the desk that I have here, about five feet,
maybe six feet, and two and a half feet deep.
That's all the space you have to put the propulsion system.
There was no opening, there was no propeller,
there was no jet, there was nothing to see.
How did it work?
How did it plow a boulevard down the hill, under power, for half an eye?
The people we interviewed on the ranch said it dug up something like five or six feet
of dirt, all the way down the hill, under power.
An airplane would have broken up in a hundred pieces, it would stay there.
That object kept moving.
What was the propulsion?
Somebody has that object, we still don't have any propulsion system that does that.
We're going back to the moon with pretty much
the same kind of rocket we had when in Project
Apollo.
It's more reliable, I hope, it's better designed, we've learned a lot.
We learned a lot about keeping people alive and functioning in those environments.
We've done all of that in fifty years, but we don't have anything like those objects
can do.
Well, Dr Jacques Follet, this has been a great
privilege for me to be with you once again.
The Trinity story is crucial to our understanding
of the history of the field of ufology.
It's a very important piece of history.
I'm honored that you've taken the time to share your work with me.
I hope that we'll have an opportunity to talk
further because I know your investigations
have been going on for decades and decades.
As much as we've covered today, we've still only scratched the surface.
I want to thank you very much for being with me today.
It will be a pleasure.
Thank you.
And for those of you watching or listening, thank you for being with us.
